title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text:
I went to Peahi last Friday November 24th, and I realize how lucky I was to only be here in Mauii when this big swell arrived.
Best day!

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Beautiful Sea Cliffs and home to the biggest waves in the world!!!

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Beautiful spot overlooking the cove. Long idyllic walk along a few sheer drops hidden by brush and treetops so beware. Don’t drive unless you have a 4x4 with at least 10inches of clearance.  Big ruts in some spots will bury a car and flip a standard SUV.  If you have off road experience, then proceed with the usual caution using a spotter to clear a drop before committing. Really fun bumping along if you can though!

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: With out a very good jeep there is no way to even get there, don’t even try when it rained recently

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text:
This review might be a little contentious. It's not that I think this is a bad spot, it's just overhyped for most of the year. If you're not there when Peahi is breaking, don't bother.

In May 2017, there was no break (obviously), but I really wanted to see this famous spot anyway. The road conditions were terrible. Even in a light 4x4, I was concerned that any rain would trap us at the bottom of the road, unable to drive out. Tons of washouts, junked/burned cars, and a couple of grades that will be very challenging in the wet.

The problem is that the sections with the steepest grades have become extremely washed out and lumpy. You can't carry much speed, so you have to pull your way up. On road tires, you can end up in trouble with any amount of rain.

To put it in perspective, we drove nearly everywhere (including Polihale) on Kauai, which was a cake walk by comparison. In short, the view is nice, but it's not any better than the 100 other cliff views in Maui. Only go out if there is a break. There will be plenty of locals to bail you out for $20 if you get stuck.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Had a unique experience that we'll remember forever.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Don’t try getting here without 4 wheel drive!!

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Insane Spot, you can hear the Thunder of the Waves from the Cliffs

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Incredible view, incredible waves. Even with a 4x4 Jeep in 4x4 low, this was a difficult drive that I STRONGLY RECOMMEND WALKING. Many stuck abandoned and trashed cars, and one AWD stuck and flooded in a deep puddle. Walk it, no tow trucks.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text:
It was great off road trail. We stopped after the sign, and i’m glad we did- there was a truck stuck closer to the end, it was risky to even try to get to the point where he was. Fair to mention he did not have 4x4. We could have potentially go through, but the last trench was really deep.
Walk from the sign was about 15-20 minutes all the way to the bottom.  Last part of the hike( descending), was a bit steep, but nothing extreme. It’s more slippery on a clay road. The beach was empty and there were no surfers that morning, so we enjoyed absolute solitude and beauty of this spot. On our way back we already met few hikers. It was around 10-11am

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: 3km walk each way on a dirt road, if you're walking back at dark get ready for some large dogs coming at you who aren't chained up by their owner

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text:
Jaws
Killer waves...4x4 only trail. Or 45min walk.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text:
Don't drive your Kia or mini van down this road!!!

Its a modest walk to the lookout ~1mi.

The hike down to the shore is a little slippery where soil and loose where needles.

Jetskis were pulling surfers in to the surf on our trip because the surf was massive one day. Pretty cool.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text:
Nice views at the end but the road in
should be taken seriously. The clay turns to ice with now traction and the road has many deep water sections and wash outs. A good 4x4 with ground clearance is the way.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: This is an off-roading trail, if there is a surf break you will have a very difficult time getting there even with 4 wheel drive. Not sure I can recommend this trail to nowhere.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text:
1st Logistics -- if you have a car, stop on the paid parking on left (don't drive it) off the main road.  If you have an SUV, you can only go 1/2 way & there's really no place to park.  If you have a 4x4, you can only go about another 500ft because the ONLY vehicle that can drive this is a Hawaiian 4x4 (jacked up ground clearance + oversized super mud whumper tires).  Finally if you hike in, give yourself time and bring water (+snack)...take all your trash out, too!

2nd Time of Day & Conditions -- 40' wave is high tide, peak wind.  If you're coming any other time, you can see just as good waves in Ho'okipa.  I still had fun, but it's hard to tell size over distance w/o a reference.

Update: Locals said moon cycle helps -- come daytime of a full moon and October is seasonally best

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: We followed Google maps and then all the sudden there was no paved road to follow.  Some local lady offered us to park by her house for $10 and we decided to walk the remaining 1.5 miles up and 1.5 miles up.  Well, it was a huge waste of time and energy.  The lookout ain't worth the effort... the lady just wanted the $10 and told us it was a great view... not so,  at least when we went.  We highly discourage people from going... but if you decide to go... don't pay the $10 to the home owners because even though the road ain't paved you can drive a few hundred yards down to an opening where you can park and then walk less and save ten bucks.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Smashing break

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: If the forecast says 40+ feet, count yourself blessed and make it down there no matter the cost. When you get to the bottom parking lot hang right to the trail to the beach.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Great view of the surfers break. Tough road to get down. It is possible in a car, but highly recommend a SUV. Our car required a push at one point. Check the surf report before going and only go if the surf is high, or you know there will be people surfing there.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: We parked at the main road and walked in. Took 30 mins each way. When we got there we found a spot amongst the trees with a pretty good view of the surfers. You are on the side of a cliff with a big drop so kids probably not advised. Bring a picnic and cheers with the locals as surfers catch the massive waves. Really fun experience! Check the forecast as the waves only break over 20ft apparently, if you see lots of cars parked at the road it's on!

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Got to see the big waves and pro surfers. Don't suggest driving in with a car. Rough road. Good folks will give you a ride in the back of their pickup. Others will charge you ten bucks. It's a long but easy walk.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: The location itself is awesome. However the (dirt) road to get there is dirty as hell. Some idiots used it as a landfill and it's just nasty all the way. Trash bags, burnt cars, engine pieces, washing machines, you name it. Awful. Oh, and we got a flat tire since debris are everywhere.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Famous spot, spoiled by a road full of trash. Locals seem very white trash, that must explain

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Amazing if the conditions are right.... do not attempt without a 4WD vehicle.  Cars overheat and get stuck in the mud.  No water, food, or facilities.  Bring anything you need and respect the locals.  Expect an international crowd.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Not much for waves the day I was here and no surfing going on at all. Fun drive to get to it though! And a nice little hike down the path.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Worth the drive for the views!!

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: This is a magical place for surfers. It's hard to get to.  It's only for very experienced surfers or those that have a death wish. The break is severe and the rocks come in quickly. If it has rained in the past day prepare for a muddy and slippery 2 mile hike. Unless of course you have an all wheel drive pickup truck with a lot of ground clearance.  Oh, it's also a good place to just junk a car, smash it, burn it, rip apart the entire thing and spray paint it.  That's what I'm told. :)

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Surf

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: It's hard to get to either 4wheel drive, lifted trucks or just walk down. But the wave is pretty amazing

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: This place is difficult to reach. Do not attempt without four wheel drive. On busy days there is a $10 shuttle that takes you down the old pineapple dirt road to the viewpoint. If visiting, I recommend this option. Many people walk down the dirt road, but prepare for a long, hot, dusty or muddy walk. The view from the cliff is best if you have a powerful zoom lense because the action is pretty far away. The last time I visited it had rained and the road was so muddy that many cars got stuck in the mud. Everyone viewing the waves also left covered in mud just from walking out to the point from the parking area. Definitely avoid this place if it has recently rained.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Best place ever

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: A place where it is hit and miss as far as waves go. It's off the beaten track so you have to drive on a dirt road that is spotted on the side with abandoned cars and high grasses and feels like a bad idea at the time. You don't need a 4x4 but it is handy. You park up the top of the hill and then you will have to walk down to the beach. Turn left and don't follow the path to the right which looks like the path to go on but you need to climb down the left side..don't slip! We got there and there was no waves at all. Day later, huge waves but we had left the island...so bit of luck required.

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Beautiful beach and huge waves! Very cool!

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Went during surf season and saw some amazing waves. Highly recommended!

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: This place will get pretty crowded when there is a large swell, but seriously that is the only time you want to go. If not too crazy, it's an easy (but narrow) drive to the lookout point. Walk down to the shoreline from there is a bit steep and can get slippery, but is seriously just 5 min or so and worth it. Bring a camera for sure in case the locals are towing in!

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: It's a journey well worth your time. Destination360 has pictures if you would like to see before you go. Avoid driving down on a muddy day as you'll get stuck. Park on the Hwy and walk in and remember to keep the aloha spirit!

title: Pe'ahi Jaws Surf Break
text: Not a place for tourists to just drive up and see. A 1 mile single lane dirt road comes to a lookout with trees and brush blocking your view of the waves you would need to hike down a steep hill to be able to see anything.

title: Peahi
text: Depending on season and recent rainfall, this road can even be a challenge for a jeep… unless you have a winch and aren’t worried about dents, dings, and scratches. We took a rental jeep with stock tires, and despite my 4x4 experience, there were moments I was worried we’d get stuck and have to pay thousands for a recovery service. My sons (5 and 7 years old) thought the drive was “flippin’ nuts!”.

title: Peahi
text: Park n hitch hike to look out, bring beer or joint to trade for ride to look out. Hike down to cove from lookout is not to same place surfers put in w buddy on jet ski nor is it easy. Jaws is for professional surfers and hardcore fans ONLY! Don't go of you're soft at anything.

title: Peahi
text: Only paddled onto 5 footers but what a spot

title: Peahi
text: Worth the hike in! Especially if the waves are high, carefully some parts of slippery, I fell and enjoyed a mud bath but still worth it! If you are lucky you may even be offered a ride back up the tough terrain! Mahalo to the awesome pair that brought us back to our car! So worth seeing.

title: Peahi
text:
This is a hit and miss spot, because the waves are often not big, and there are easier beaches to visit. On a normal day just hit ho'okipa. The forecast was for 25'+ for a few days on our trip so we wandered down. We found a spot at the start of the road immediately off the highway and walked the whole way. Its maybe a mile to the upper lookout and there are a bunch of trails that take you to the rocky beach. The road is not driveable in a car or minivan. A truck with 4wd and AT tires will have no problem. There was a little mud and some nig puddles but the road was easy to walk, and not that steep. The trails down to the beach were steeper and more slippery, but easy in good trail runners or light hikers.

There is a river and lush jungle that I would like to explore next time!

title: Peahi
text: A natural wonder of the world. Absolutely take your breath away. Many thanks go out to the surfers who risk everything when this place is charging!! Without the worldwide interest in this beautiful, but dangerous sport, Peahi has become a world spectacle for all to see and enjoy. It's  a challenge of major proportions to the producer, Handsome Buggah Productions to have the preparations ready on a 6 day window for a contest that lasts 1 week in a 2 month period, when the waves start coming from the N Pacific. Rain, wind, mud all conditions for the competitors and the production and water safety crews.

title: Peahi
text: All the beaches are wonderful for different reasons .. the view is spectacular the father you go north... Less sandy beach but amazing views

title: Peahi
text: See the wind forecast before you go!!! We spent an hour walking under the hot sun to end up seeing nothing cause the waves didnt form at that time. Supper disappointed.

title: Peahi
text: Beautiful beach to stop and watch surfers, kite surfers and feel the beach vibes. Big waves, cool breezes, sunning Sea Turtles and a Hawaiian Monk Seal hanging out.

text: It was a lovely 1.35 mile walk down a dirt road surrounded by tall beautiful grass. It was a hot and low tide day so we didn’t have many companions. Once at the overlook we had a great view of the beach but didn’t see the extreme waves. That was okay. It was still a great experience.

title: Peahi
text: Make sure you go with a SUV all wheel drive otherwise you will be stuck. If you do get stuck, walk back to the houses, a local will tow you. His number is on the fence. Also FYI there are very few big waives in July.

title: Peahi
text: We have some land that we have been paying, so retirement will be in Hawaii dude. . This is a must see for the tourist and local people. Jaws has been around for many centuries now and, it's believed that the Waves are getting bigger and more difficult to Surf. ‍♂️.

title: Peahi
text:
After locals showed us how to hike in on a 1.67 mi winding path between 2 fenced off rancheros, my bro & I found this serene bodhisattva tree, 50-60 feet up a cliffside, to sit, meditate, & marvel at the surging 10-12 foot wave swarms below.

Do not go here unless you are sober and exceedingly careful as it's a sudden drop off to certain death on the crags below!

title: Peahi
text:
It’s nice when you get back in there. But word to the wise have a 4 Wheel Dr and don’t go after it rains the road is very Winding, steep in places and can be very slick. Take your time if you’re driving back here and ill be worth your time.
Please hit “Like” if this was helpful. Thanks.

title: Peahi
text: surf was big, local camera men said 30/40'.  Kai Lenny and 1 other guy out tow in surfing.  2 boats, 4 jet skis, at least 3 camera crews on site.   surfing sure is different in Hawaii.  4x4 mandatory to make this drive.  memorable experience for sure

title: Peahi
text: Remote spot on the north shore. Wave riders from all over test their skills on the massive Jaws Break.  Great to hike down to the shoreline. Lots of dead cars and trash on the 1.5 mile dirt road down to the break.

title: Peahi
text: Great place to see surfers and nice waves! Beautiful sight to see, God’s blue ocean! A must to see the place. Maui no ka oi!!

text: Einmal muss man hier gewesen sein um die gigantischen Wellen gesehen zu haben - einfach nur wow!

title: Peahi
text: 4WD car would be more suitable for this place

title: Peahi
text: Almost made it before the rain!

title: Peahi
text:
BEAUTIFUL stop. Unfortunately there wasn't that much activity going on with the waves, but it was a great stop to check out this legendary place.

BEWARE, people weren't kidding when they said that there's a dirt road. We asked the cashier in the shop before the road to Jaws and she helped us locate the place. However, she did not say how intense this road was. It felt like we went off roading - dirt road, only one lane (hope that no one is going the opposite way), holes everywhere, alot of trash, trenches.... Probably took us about 30minutes of slow driving since we were in a sedan. I would highly recommend ensuring you have a SUV when driving these roads.

Would I recommend this place? It's only worth the drive if you're a HUGE FAN of Jaws and MUST SEE the place even if the waves aren't massive. Then check it out. Other than that, I wouldn't recommend it. The drive, the sight of trash and lack of activity wasn't worth the drive.

You can see the same view in other areas.

title: Peahi
text: I drove back here a week ago while on vacation. First off have the proper vehicle. SUV/trucks are the ONLY way to drive back here. You can drive a regular car  however I highly recommend you park and 'walk-in' and the road (dirt) tends to 'gully' and 'washout' after any decent rainfall. Once you reach the roads end (maybe two miles at best) you come to a cliff. Watch the edge! There is some vegetation overgrowth and then just straight down to the rocks. To actually get to the beachhead you have to hike down a small single back trail probably 200'-300' in elevation thru dense rain forest. As someone who has never even held a surfboard it is a lot to ponder why someone would risk life and limb to surf such a fierce and rocky break? Whatever it's still cool to see and take pictures. Safety first!
